awd_titl_txt: Multi-scale models of thermo-mechanical feedbacks on a soft,  wet bed
awd_abstract_narration:
Sea level is observed to be rising at an accelerating rate.  A significant portion of this rise is derived from glaciers.  Glacier sliding speeds and the discharge rates of the ice streams and outlet glaciers that drain Earth?s major ice sheets are primarily controlled by conditions at their beds.  This project will use models to explore constraints on the bed conditions that control sliding.  This will begin at small scales where the physics are understood from experiments and the results will be used to rigorously account for the effects of heterogeneities across the larger scales of observed glacier flow and associated landscape development.

The project will improve glacier modeling and, ultimately, contribute to improved scenarios of future sea level rise.  It will contribute to STEM workforce development by providing support for the training of a post-doctoral associate.  Five undergraduate students will be entrained effectively into the research program.  Outreach to middle schools will be achieved through the PI?s participation in summer teacher workshops, followed by co-development and co-teaching of a project on glaciers and sea level rise.  This will include the development of a hands-on demonstration.

The principal investigator proposes to develop a hierarchy of models aimed at exploring the consequences of thermo-mechanical coupling between ice, water, and till. His studies will span a very wide range of time scales: from the elastic response to tidal forcing at transiently locked portions of the bed, to the decadal periods over which significant topographic modifications take place. He will also examine a broad range of length scales, including the transitional regions accessed by seepage flows between conduits, and basin-wide responses to modeled and observed topographic roughness. Water pressures close to flotation reduce the resistance to frictional sliding and bring the effective stress supported by sediment particle contacts to within the range typical of the upper few meters of soil in subaerial environments. Long-established, experimentally supported thermo-mechanical treatments of ice-water-sediment interactions under such conditions have only recently been applied to the subglacial environment. Further work is needed to fully integrate this understanding and its implications for glacier sliding and landscape development. This proposal targets a selection of model problems aimed at elucidating the thermo-mechanical constraints on behavior near transitions in basal properties, rigorously accounting for the effects of heterogeneities across the range of scales relevant to modern observations. With the intuition gained from focused studies on carefully selected systems, the principal investigator will develop strategies for parameterizing the model predictions so that they can be incorporated in large-scale simulations of glacier and ice sheet dynamics.

por.por_cntn:
Glaciers and ice sheets supply additional water to the world's oceans that drives increases in mean sea level and threatens the survival of coastal communities, infrastructure and ecosystems. Forecasts for this behavior are needed urgently to develop informed mitigation strategies, but their accuracy is limited currently by uncertainty in how changing conditions will affect glacier sliding speeds. To address this need, our project has focused on examining the crucial interactions between ice, minerals and liquid water that control the sliding behavior along the beds of the world's fastest glaciers, which are generally found to sit on water-saturated sediments (aka soft, wet beds). 

In research performed by the PI, and a postdoctoral researcher, who together mentored graduate students, and undergraduate researchers, the project team has demonstrated that subtle variations in the melting temperature that accompany variations in water pressure and ice stress have significant implications for glacier behavior. These include: 1. a mechanism involving the tendency for ice to sink into underlying sediments (when the amount of glacier weight that is not supported by the underlying water pressure exceeds a threshold) that gives a new explanation for why the gravitational "driving stresses" that produce glacier motion tend to fall within a very narrow range in comparison with much larger ranges in ice thickness and surface slope; 2. a related description of how sediments were incorporated into the base of the Laurentide Ice Sheet that covered much of Canada and the northern States during the last ice age and episodically discharged rapidly (i.e. slid quickly) to send armadas of icebergs into the Atlantic during so-called "Heinrich events"; 3. a correction to venerable textbook treatments of "regelation" - the term given to melting and refreezing as ice slides past small obstacles - that shows the process to be more than ten times faster than previously appreciated;  4. a new explanation for the way in which millimeter-thick layers of ice that sometimes contain fine, dispersed sediments are incorporated into (and hence able to affect the frictional resistance to) the sliding of ice along the glacier bed;  and 5. a new understanding for why some glaciers are able to suddenly lurch forward by a mechanism similar to that which causes earthquakes. 

In addition to the enumerated contributions to the published scientific literature mentioned above, the proposal team also took laboratory demonstrations to a Eugene middle school and a museum to illustrate the science of ice flow with syrup experiments in an age-appropriate, relatable manner. Further, the proposal team extended the scientific impact of their efforts by showing how aspects of their work could be applied to both better understand the formation and concentration of icy molecules known as natural gas hydrates that are found beneath the seafloor in places like the Oregon and Carolinian coasts, and also how the destabilization of these hydrate deposits can result in submarine landslides. Two project undergraduates championed their research experience on  successful applications to graduate school and subsequently completed Master of Science degrees,  with one staying at the University of Oregon and performing thesis work devoted to a project-related topic - the thermal controls on "ice stream" flow;  the project postdoctoral researcher who was mentored during his time at the University of Oregon was subsequently hired to a tenure-track faculty position at Dartmouth College. Further research that extends the work completed during this proposal is ongoing on several fronts, providing confidence that our ability to better forecast changes in sliding behavior and attendant sea level changes will continue to improve.
